title-group.article-title: Study on debris flow discharge characteristics of check dam spillway

fn.p: Note: This paper is part of the special topic, Flow and Civil Structures.

contrib-group.aff: 1 Key Laboratory of Mountain Hazards and Earth Surface Process, CAS, Chengdu 610299, China
2 University of Chinese Academy of Science, Beijing 100049, China
3 China Railway Eryuan Engineering Group Company, Ltd., Chengdu 610031, China

corresp.label: a)
corresp.bold: Author to whom correspondence should be addressed:

license.license-p: Published under an exclusive license by AIP Publishing.

abstract.p: After a check dam is filled with sediment, the debris flow will flow out from the spillway. Insufficient discharge capacity of the spillway can lead to debris flow scouring the dam's shoulder and foundation. Therefore, it is necessary to study the discharge capacity of the spillway. It is of great importance for further optimizing the structural design of the check dam. This article analyzes discharge characteristics of debris flow of a spillway through a series of flume experiments. According to the motion states, it can be divided into five stages: contact stage of the spillway, flushing and climbing stage, increasing and reflux stage, stable discharge stage, and final discharge stage. We analyzed the influencing factors of the discharge capacity, including the type of spillway, bulk density of debris flow, scale of debris flow, flume gradient, and effective opening width of the spillway. Furthermore, we derived a calculation formula of discharge for the spillway based on Bernoulli's principle. Finally, we considered the influence of the ratio of flow area and Froude number to the discharge coefficient and established a calculation method of discharge. Consequently, we compared the calculated results with the measured results and found them to be in good agreement. Our research results provide a quantitative calculation method for the design of spillways and energy dissipation and erosion prevention projects under check dams, which is beneficial for improving engineering value and for better serving disaster prevention and reduction efforts.

funding-source.named-content: National Natural Science Foundation of China

sec.label: I.
sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: As a natural disaster, debris flow poses great harm ( Cucchiaro et al., 2019 ). Check dams are one of the most effective prevention and control measures to deal with debris flow disasters ( Jakob et al., 2005 ; Hübl and Suda, 2008; and Piton and Recking, 2017). However, some engineering problems may also arise, as demonstrated by the 2003 Fukang mudslide incident, where the toe of the check dam was severely eroded by sediment ( Remaître, 2006; Remaître et al., 2008 ). Similarly, in the Wenchuan County area of Sichuan Province, China, the erosion caused by debris flow led to the suspension of dam foundation ( Cai, 2012) and damage to the apron and the submerged dam ( Zhang et al., 2023 ). The crest of the check dam is usually designed as a spillway that can transfer the instantaneous peak flow of extreme events ( VanDine, 1996; Ono et al., 2004 ; and Rudolf-Miklau and Suda, 2012). In erosion events, insufficient discharge capacity of the spillway can also lead to debris flow scouring the dam's shoulder and foundation. Therefore, it is necessary to conduct research on the discharge capacity of spillways.

Many scholars have conducted relevant research on the discharge capacity of a spillway, mainly treating overflow at the spillway as weir flow, including pointed and wide topped weirs ( Piton and Recking, 2016; Negm et al., 2002 ). They mainly model the calculation of discharge coefficient ( Aydin et al., 2011 ; Roushangar et al., 2018 ). Sargison and Percy (2009) analyzed the influence of upstream and downstream slope on the discharge coefficient of wide crest weirs. Scholars have also accurately measured and predicted the discharge calculation models of composite weirs and wide crest weirs with different shapes ( Martinez et al., 2005 ; Salmasi, 2011). The discharge calculation formula should be revised based on dimensional analysis and other theories and applied to different types of weirs ( Bijankhan et al., 2013 ; Ferro, 2012). Based on the principle of equal weir flow and wave flow, the relationship between the maximum discharge of instantaneous dam failure and weir flow should be established ( Fang, 2012). The overflow of spillway mentioned earlier is mostly studied in the context of water conservancy, and there is relatively little research on the debris flow. Due to its unique fluid properties, debris flow differs from water flow.

In terms of debris flow, some have established a relationship between the discharge of water and sediment, the opening of dam, and sediment characteristics ( Armanini and Larcher, 2001; Armanini et al., 2006 ). Mizuyama et al. (1994) conducted a study on the discharge coefficient and downstream sedimentation morphology of dam. Wang (1996) established a formula for calculating the discharge capacity of a spillway. However, they did not have a standard for selecting discharge coefficient. Lin (2015) explored the formula for calculating the discharge of debris flows through the spillway, but he did not eliminate the influence of dimensionality. Scholars have estimated the discharge coefficient of debris flow while considering sediment concentration ( Kim et al., 2019 ), but they have overlooked the impact of the spillway. Zheng (2019) established a relationship between the discharge morphology of mud tongue and factors such as bulk density, particle size distribution, and longitudinal slope. Some scholars have also predicted the trajectory of debris flow after passing through the spillway ( Chen et al., 2016a , 2016b). Furthermore, they considered the impact of the spillway with different lateral shrinkage rates on the energy dissipation rate of debris flow on the thrust body ( Chen et al., 2016a , 2016b). However, their studies focus mainly on the movement characteristics of debris flows after passing through spillway, and there is relatively little research on the process of passing through a spillway.

After the check dam is filled with sediment, the debris flow will flow out of the spillway. To study the discharge capacity of the spillway, we conducted model experiments. Based on the assumption that the check dam is full, we theoretically derived a calculation formula for discharge. Furthermore, we selected five factors, including the type of spillway, bulk density, scale, slope, and effective opening width, to analyze their impact on discharge characteristics and discharge capacity. We also considered the impact of the contraction effect of the spillway on the discharge coefficient. Finally, a calculation formula for the discharge capacity was established. This provides a quantitative calculation method for the design of the spillway of the check dam and energy dissipation and erosion prevention project under the dam, which is beneficial for improving the engineering value and better serving disaster prevention and reduction efforts.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Similarity analysis
sec.p:
The design basis for model experiments is similarity theory. Only when model meets the similarity condition with actual situation can situation in the prototype be inferred from the results of the model experiments. It is generally believed that both the model and prototype must satisfy the three major similarities of geometric similarity, kinematic similarity, and dynamic similarity in principle. Considering the scale effect of flume experiments, we refer to the method proposed by Scheidl et al. (2013) and Scheidl et al. (2015) . For kinematic similarity and dynamic similarity, Zhang (1989) believes that for models with short river sections, where water flow changes significantly along the course and there is severe interference from hydraulic structures, or where Froude numbers are high, the influence of resistance is relatively small compared to the influence of the inertial force. Therefore, only similarity of inertial force to gravity ratio can be considered, while similarity of resistance to gravity ratio allows for certain deviations. Iverson (1997) also believes that for dynamic similarity criterion between model experiments of debris flow and prototype events of debris flow, if the Froude number is equal, it can approximate momentum transport and dynamic stress characteristics of debris flow to a certain extent. Consequently, physical model experiment of this study should follow the principle that the Froude number of simulated debris flow and prototype debris flow is equal. Considering the influence of slope of flume ( Sun et al., 2021 ), the Froude number is expressed as
F r =
v
g h
cos
θ
,
(1) where,
v
is the velocity of debris flow fluid, m/s;
g
is the acceleration of gravity, m/s 2;
h
is the characteristic length of the fluid, which is the depth of debris flow, m;
θ
is the slope of the flume.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Experimental equipment and devices
sec.p: The experimental setup includes a flume with a hopper for storing debris flow of the test, and the dimensions of the channel are 4000 × 200 × 300 mm 3. Observation equipment includes four high-speed cameras (GoPro HERO7 Black, 1080p, 240 frames/s), which are used to capture the motion state of debris flow when it passes through the spillway.

A mud meter (with a collection frequency of 2000 Hz and a measurement accuracy of 0.1 mm) records real-time changes in the mud level before and after the debris flow passes through the spillway. The spillway model is placed at the tail of flume, and a recycling bin is arranged directly below the spillway model to recycle debris flow samples. The experimental equipment and devices are shown in Fig. 1.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Experimental material
sec.p: Materials used in the experiment were taken from debris flow accumulation area in the Gan gully in Longmenshan Town, Pengzhou City, China. To reduce possible impact of boundary effects on the results, the particle size of the largest particle in the selected debris flow needs to be less than or equal to 1/5 of the width of the flume. Therefore, coarse gravel with a diameter greater than 40 mm is manually screened, and only the original debris flow samples with a diameter of less than 40 mm are retained. The maximum characteristic particle size is d 90 = 20 mm, the median particle size is d 50 = 4, and d 30 = 20 mm. The particle size distribution curve obtained is shown in Fig. 2.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Experimental design
sec.p: The variable parameters selected for the experiment are mainly of three types: parameters of debris flow, parameters of channel, and parameters of the spillway, as shown in Table I. Parameters of debris flow include bulk density (13, 15, 17, 19, and 21 kN/m 3) and scale (10, 15, 20, 25, and 30 l). After a field investigation, it was found that when the check dam was filled with sediment, its longitudinal slope was relatively gentle, mostly between 0.05 and 0.15 ( Zhang, 2021). Accordingly, to better simulate actual gullies, we set the slope of the flume to be between 5° and 9°. Parameters of the spillway include the type of spillway (rectangular or trapezoidal) and the opening form of the spillway (depth of wide-shallow type is 100 mm, depth of general type is 150 mm, depth of narrow-deep type is 200 mm). In order to compare the influence of the parameters of the spillway on discharge, we kept the area of the spillway unchanged, all of which were 15 000 mm 2. Experimental parameters are shown in Table I.

tr.td: Wide-shallow type (depth is 100 mm), general type (depth is 150 mm), narrow-deep type (depth is 200 mm)

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Theoretical hypothesis
sec.p: Debris flow passing through the spillway is complex, turbulent non-Newtonian fluid, and determining assumptions can help simplify treatment. Therefore, we assume that the distribution of the two-phase fluid near the spillway is uniform. Furthermore, temperature is constant when the debris flow contacts with the spillway, and there is no velocity difference between solid and liquid phases. At the same time, we assume that the velocity distribution of the debris flow passing through the spillway is equal and the mud depth is consistent across the entire section. Since we are considering the situation where the check dam is filled with sediment, we have ignored the material exchange between debris flow and sediment in the original gully.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Analysis of discharge capacity of debris flow
sec.p:
The debris flow passing through the spillway can be regarded as the overflow of a wide crest weir ( Lin, 2015). However, unlike overflow of a wide crest weir, there is a slope of sedimentation behind the check dam. We take the 0–0 section as the reference plane, as shown in Fig. 3. For a certain upstream section 1 and section 2 at the spillway, the Bernoulli energy conservation equation can be used to obtain the following:

The discharge coefficient is related to factors such as the bulk density of debris flow and the degree of mud depth shrinkage when the debris flow passes through the spillway. Due to differences in discharge coefficients under different influencing factors, it is not possible to directly calculate the value of discharge coefficients. Therefore, the discharge coefficient can be determined by measuring discharge, calculating the total head difference, the width of the spillway, and other parameters, and finally calculating the discharge coefficient backward.

Due to the fluctuation in the discharge coefficient over time, during a single flow event, the discharge coefficient is relatively large at the beginning and fluctuates greatly. This is because of the significant increase and reflux generated by the early debris flow, and when the debris flow enters the stable stage, the discharge coefficient shows a stable change and a slow decrease in trend ( Lin, 2015). Therefore, calculation of discharge coefficient in this article mainly focuses on the stable discharge stage, and for the subsequent discharge stage, decrease in discharge coefficient cannot reflect the true discharge capacity of the spillway. Through an analysis of the experimental phenomena and data on mud depth, it is found that the mud depth and velocity of the debris flow do not change significantly during the stable discharge stage. Accordingly, using this stage as a reference for studying the discharge capacity of a spillway has certain reference significance.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Theoretical derivation of discharge coefficient
sec.p: Reduced-scale experiments can interpret the results obtained from small-scale experiments as similar to those obtained from large-scale experiments or natural events. We use dimensionless numbers to ensure that ratio between fluid stress and particle stress in model experiments matches in the prototype. Froude numbers dominate the behavior of geophysical flow at a macroscopic level. Froude numbers are commonly used to determine whether debris flows are dominated by inertia or gravity ( Jakob et al., 2005 ; Hübl et al., 2009 ; and Choi et al., 2016 ). Froude numbers of debris flows in nature may be relatively small, such as the measured Froude number of debris flows in Jiangjia gully ( Hu et al., 2011 ), which ranges from 1.5 to 2.0. This key dimensionless parameter is widely used in the study of debris flow.

The experiment of flume is crucial for understanding landslides, debris flows, and other related geological experiments ( Iverson and Vallance, 2001; Iverson and George, 2014; and Iverson and George, 2016). The scaling ratio can be obtained through dimensional analysis or by dimensionless control equations ( Wang et al., 2018 ). We use dimensional analysis to study scaling relationship of debris flow. Based on the layout of model, derivation of the above-mentioned discharge formula, and results of the experiment, we believe that discharge of debris flow through the spillway is related to properties of debris flow, parameters of spillway, and channel conditions of flume. Due to the various influencing parameters of spillway, including different types and opening widths, as well as the fact that contraction effect of spillway is the main reason for differences in discharge capacity, we believe that flow area of debris flow passing through the spillway is one of the important factors. Therefore, we define this factor as the ratio of flow area of debris flow passing through the spillway to the flow area of the upstream section before the spillway, which is dimensionless.

Therefore, we believe that discharge of debris flow passing through the spillway is related to multiple variables such as the flow velocity
v
, the bulk density
ρ
, the acceleration of gravity
g

H 0

B

Q = f ( v , ρ , g , B ,

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Discharge characteristics of debris flow
sec.p:
We can divide the flow behavior of debris flow through the spillway into five stages according to its motion state: contact stage of spillway, flushing and climbing stage, increasing and reflux stage, stable discharge stage, and final discharge stage. Figure 5 shows the detailed process in the five stages. Bulk density of debris flow in this experiment is 17 kN/m 3, and model of spillway is a trapezium with a depth of 200 mm, an upper opening width of 100 mm, and a lower opening width of 50 mm.
(1)
Contact stage of spillway
After the hopper at the upper end of the flume opens the gate, the debris flow moves downstream along the flume at a certain depth and velocity, and the debris flow head contacts the spillway.
(2)
Flushing and climbing stage
After the first contact between the debris flow head and the spillway, due to the upward space of debris flow movement, the debris flow head undergoes a climbing motion from the bottom to the top along the surface of the model on both sides of the spillway under the strong squeezing effect of subsequent flow. Therefore, the velocity of debris flow continuously decreases with the increase in climbing distance. At the same time, the debris flow on both sides will change the direction of the motion due to the effect of contraction of the spillway, causing it to concentrate toward the middle part.
(3)
Increasing and reflux stage
When debris flow climbs along the spillway, due to the constraint effect of the spillway, the debris flow lacks the necessary space for movement, and its obstruction effect is more obvious, resulting in impact backflow. Some debris flows generate backflow, while others are discharged through the spillway.
(4)
Stable discharge stage
During this stage, debris flow steadily passes through the spillway. At the same time, the phenomenon of backflow also exists. However, the height of the debris flow backflow remains consistent, and the change in velocity is also minimal. Compared with other stages, the duration of the debris flow movement will also be longer.
(5)
Ultimately discharge stage
During this stage, due to the continuous discharge of debris flows, velocity of the remaining debris flows gradually slows down, and the mud depth at the spillway also gradually decreases. Finally, the debris flow flowed down from the spillway until a burst of debris flow ended.

caption.p: The flow stage of debris flow.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Influence of factors on discharge coefficient
sec.p: The calculation of discharge coefficient in this article mainly focuses on the stable discharge stage of spillway. According to experimental results, stable discharge stage lasts relatively long. Through an analysis of experimental phenomena and data of mud depth, the mud depth and velocity of debris flow during stable discharge stage do not change much, which can reflect true discharge capacity. Therefore, using this stage as a reference for studying discharge capacity of spillway has a certain reference significance.

sec.title: Types of spillway
sec.p: We divide the types of spillway into rectangle and trapezium. Scale of debris flow is set at 20 L, and the slope of the flume is 7°. The discharge coefficients of each type of spillway are shown in Fig. 6. We found that discharge coefficient of a trapezium is greater than a rectangle, reaching 0.3–0.4. The discharge coefficient can effectively reflect the discharge capacity of the spillway, and a large discharge coefficient indicates a strong overcurrent capacity. We analyzed the reasons for the significant differences in their discharge coefficients. By comparing their hydraulic radius when passing through the spillway, it is generally found that the hydraulic radius of a trapezium is larger than that of a rectangle. Furthermore, the larger the hydraulic radius, the greater the discharge of debris flow, and the stronger its discharge capacity.

caption.p: Discharge coefficient of different types of spillway.

sec.title: Bulk density of debris flow
sec.p: Bulk densities of debris flow are set to 13, 15, 17, 19, and 21 kN/m 3, respectively. We take the trapezoidal spillway as an example, which includes wide-shallow, general, and narrow deep types. Scale of debris flow is set to 20 l, and the slope of the flume is set to 7°. The relationship between discharge coefficient and bulk density is shown in Fig. 7. Discharge coefficient shows a decreasing trend with the increase in bulk density. The reason for phenomenon is due to differences in the properties of debris flow, which results in different flow characteristics. Debris flow with high bulk density has a high content of fine particles, strong bonding between coarse and fine particles, good overall performance, and poor fluidity. Therefore, when debris flow passes through the spillway, mud depth and velocity are both small, and the discharge is also small. However, when bulk density is low, the opposite is true.

caption.p: Relationship between discharge coefficient and bulk density.

sec.title: Scale of debris flow
sec.p: We set the scale of debris flow as 10, 15, 20, 25, and 30 l, respectively, with a bulk density of 17 kN/m 3 and a slope of 7°. We take the rectangular and trapezoidal spillways as examples, with the general opening form. Through an analysis of experimental data, we finally obtained the relationship between discharge coefficient and scale of debris flow, as shown in Fig. 8. The discharge coefficient obviously shows an increasing trend with the rising of scale. It results in a significant increase in both velocity and mud depth. Consequently, the calculated discharge coefficient will be larger.

caption.p: Relationship between discharge coefficient and scale of debris flow.

sec.title: Slope of flume
sec.p: We set the slope of flume to 5°, 6°, 7°, 8°, and 9°, respectively, with a bulk density of 17 kN/m 3 and a scale of 15 l. We take the rectangular and trapezoidal spillways as examples, with the spillway type being general. We finally obtained the relationship between discharge coefficient and slope, as shown in Fig. 9. It shows an increasing trend with the increase in the slope. It is due to the significant enhancement of kinetic energy of debris flow when passing through the spillway. The larger mud depth and velocity result in the growing of discharge coefficient.

caption.p: Relationship between discharge coefficient and slope of flume.

sec.title: Effective opening width of spillway
sec.p: We define effective opening width as the ratio of flow area to the depth of spillway. Due to the equal flow area for each model, which is 150 cm 2, their effective opening widths can be obtained by setting different depths. Including narrow-deep type (depth is 200 mm), general type (depth is 150 mm), and wide-shallow type (depth is 100 mm). Taking a trapezoidal spillway as an example, variation of discharge coefficient is shown in Fig. 10. Discharge coefficient shows a decreasing trend with the increase in effective opening width under the same bulk density. Therefore, discharge capacity is maximum for narrow-deep type, moderate for general type, and minimum for wide-shallow type. During the movement of debris flows, the average velocity at the middle position is greater than that on both sides. When the effective opening width is small, the main debris flow is at the central position. At the same time, the phenomenon of increasing and reflux is more obvious compared to other types, which enhances the advantage of velocity. Accordingly, discharge capacity of narrow-deep is stronger, and the discharge coefficient will also be larger. On the contrary, other types of increasing and reflux are not very obvious, and the advantage of velocity in the middle is also weak.

caption.p: Relationship between discharge coefficient and effective opening width.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Calculation method of discharge for spillway
sec.p: We divide the discharge coefficient of debris flow into the changes caused by Froude number and the ratio of flow area, as shown in Figs. 11 and 12. The discharge coefficient increases with increasing Froude number and the ratio of flow area. Due to the increase in Froude number, the mobility of debris flow is stronger, and the integrity is weaker. Therefore, when it interacts with the spillway, it is more likely to produce the phenomenon of increasing and reflux, resulting in an enhancement in the discharge coefficient. Similarly, due to the increase in the ratio of flow area, the contraction effect of spillway is more obvious, and increasing and reflux will be more evident, resulting in strong discharge capacity.

caption.p: Relationship between discharge coefficient and Froude number.
Relationship between discharge coefficient and ratio of flow area.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Factors affecting flowing
sec.p: We know that influence factors of debris flow through the spillway should include at least three aspects. First, the characteristics of gully where debris flow occurs. As a common geological and hydrological hazard, debris flow has special catastrophic characteristics due to combination of heavy rainfall (accumulated rainfall of several hundred millimeters within a few hours) and strong terrain (steep small watershed) ( Gaume et al., 2009 ; Borga et al., 2014 ). In the event of debris flow, in addition to the magnitude and duration of rainfall events, the importance of terrain and morphological characteristics of the watershed has been recognized to a certain extent, and watershed morphological variables have been used by empirical methods to predict the size of debris flows ( Rickenmann, 1999; Coe et al., 2003 ). Therefore, in steep terrain, peak flow during the outbreak of debris flow will also be greater, and its destructive power will be stronger. We simulate the channel where debris flow occurs as an adjustable slope in a flume. According to our experimental results ( Fig. 9), when the slope is steep, discharge of debris flow passing through the spillway will also be higher, and the final obtained discharge coefficient will also be larger. Due to the limitations of the experimental site, we overlooked the influence of the width of the channel on the discharge of spillway, which will also be considered in our subsequent experiments. Similarly, the amount of loose sediment stored in watershed catchment areas plays a crucial role in the outbreak of debris flows ( Hungr et al., 1984 ; Marchi and D'Agostino, 2004). In these narrow valleys, a large amount of loose sediment is occasionally transported by debris flows with high intensity and low frequency events, which is also considered the main cutting process in steep terrain ( Montgomery and Buffington, 1997). Therefore, in areas with a large amount of loose sediment, scale of debris flow will also be larger under the influence of extreme rainfall events. We change scale of debris flow by controlling the total amount of debris flow materials. According to the experimental results ( Fig. 8), in a larger scale of debris flow, the discharge passing through the spillway will increase sharply, ultimately leading to an enhancement in the discharge coefficient.

Second, the influencing factors of debris flows themselves. It is generally believed that debris flows are composed of two substances, namely solid part and fluid part. Solid part includes coarse-grained sediments such as boulders, cobbles, and gravel, while fluid part includes suspended sediments such as sand, silt, and clay ( Meyrat et al., 2022 ). Although particle size distribution of solid materials may be important in debris flow dynamics ( Johnson et al., 2012 ), we did not consider the influence of different particle sizes in our experiments, which is also one of the conditions that need to be considered in our subsequent experiments. In this series of experiments, we considered different volume densities, namely bulk density of debris flow referred to in this article. It is composed of solid particles mixed with different amounts of mud. We always assume that solid and fluid components are completely saturated and do not contain interstitial air, which is consistent with most existing debris flow models ( Iverson and George, 2014; Kowalski and McElwaine, 2013; and Pudasaini, 2012) that solid and fluid components are two independent phases. According to our experimental results ( Fig. 7), discharge coefficient shows a decreasing trend with the increase in bulk density. Debris flow with a high bulk density have a high content of fine particles and strong bonding between coarse and fine particles, resulting in good overall performance. However, their flowability is poor, resulting in smaller mud depth and velocity when debris flow passes through the spillway. Therefore, calculated discharge coefficient is also smaller. Similarly, low bulk density exhibits the opposite trend.

Third, the morphological characteristics of spillway. Researchers have pointed out through experimental data that discharge coefficient is related to height to width ratio of weir ( Bos, 1989). Some people have also found that discharge coefficient depends on the ratio of weir head to weir height and have proposed an empirical formula for discharge coefficient ( Aydin et al., 2011 ). They consider discharge at the spillway as a model of weir flow, so discharge coefficient is related to parameters of spillway. Scholars have fitted the upper and lower thrust profiles of rectangular pointed weirs using equations to obtain a formula for discharge coefficient, which involves parameters such as the width and height of weir ( Bagheri and Heidarpour, 2010). Consequently, we believe that the width and height of spillway are closely related to the discharge coefficient. Moreover, different types of spillway can also have a certain impact on the discharge coefficient. In this series of experiments, we considered different types of spillway and different effective opening widths. Based on our experimental results ( Figs. 6 and 10), we analyzed the differences in discharge capacity among rectangle and trapezium and reasons for these differences. At the same time, we also compared and analyzed the differences in discharge capacity among different effective opening widths. However, there is one type of spillway that we did not consider, which is a complex shape. This shape is formed by combining a rectangle and trapezium ( Chan et al., 2020 ). When the scale of debris flow is small, it can flow out from the lower part. This form is more complex and presents patterns that may differ from the rectangle and trapezium, which will be further considered in our future experiments.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Calculation of discharge
sec.p: After analyzing the influencing factors of discharge capacity, we established a calculation formula for discharge of debris flow through the spillway, as shown in formulas (15) and (16). In the formula, we comprehensively consider the influence of two dimensionless parameters, Froude number and the ratio of flow area. We know that Froude number is commonly used to determine whether debris flows are dominated by inertia or gravity ( Jakob et al., 2005 ; Hübl et al., 2009 ; and Choi et al., 2016 ). Froude number can also reflect the differences in the properties of debris flows. For example, under the same experimental conditions, Froude number of low bulk density is significantly greater than that of high bulk density. The ratio of flow area can reflect the impact of different spillway on the discharge. Finally, we compared the computational formulas with research results of previous scholars, as shown in Fig. 13. First, we can see that there is a difference from the results ( Wang, 1996). As he mainly focuses on the rectangular spillway, we analyzed that discharge capacity of a rectangular spillway is smaller than that of a trapezoidal spillway. Therefore, the results calculated using his formulas will be smaller than the actual situation, which is consistent with the results reflected in the graph. Furthermore, compared with Bos (1989) and Aydin et al. (2011) , their computational expressions yield larger results than those of this study. This is because their experimental material is clean water, and the density of clean water is much smaller than that of debris flow. According to results of this study, discharge coefficient shows a decreasing trend with the increase in bulk density. Therefore, their discharge coefficient will be much larger than the calculated discharge coefficient in this study. It is consistent with the results reflected in the graph. This formula is applicable to hydraulic engineering, but not to the prevention and control of debris flows. Consequently, this study has made improvements on their basis, taking into account the influence of debris flow and spillway on the discharge coefficient, which makes final calculation results more consistent with the actual situation. Due to limitations in our experimental design, to reduce errors in the calculation results, the equation used in this study has certain limitations: Froude number applicable to debris flow is 1.55–3.38; volume concentration of mud and sand in debris flow is 0.182–0.667; and longitudinal slope of gully is 0.087–0.158. It should be noted that the calculation expression in this study is applicable to the condition that the check dam is filled with sediments.

caption.p: Comparison of the results of this study with other studies.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p:
This study analyzed the discharge characteristics and influencing factors of discharge capacity of a spillway through a series flume experiments and established a calculation method for the discharge under the condition that the check dam is filled with sediments. The research results provide a quantitative calculation method for the design of spillway and the energy dissipation and erosion prevention engineering under the dam. The main experimental results are as follows:
(1)
We can divide the flow behavior of debris flow through the spillway into five stages according to its motion state: contact stage of spillway, flushing and climbing stage, increasing and reflux stage, stable discharge stage, and ultimately discharge stage.
(2)
Based on Bernoulli's conservation principle, we are considering the influence of Froude number and the ratio of flow area and have derived the calculation formula of discharge for the spillway.
(3)
We have revealed the influence of different factors on the discharge capacity of the spillway. While keeping the flow area parameter constant, the discharge capacity of a trapezoidal spillway is greater than that of a rectangular spillway. The discharge capacity shows a decreasing trend with the increase in bulk density, but there may be differences in the complex shape. The discharge capacity shows an enhancement trend with increasing debris flow scale. The discharge capacity is larger with the increase of slope. The discharge capacity shows a decreasing trend with the increase in effective opening width.
(4)
We have established a calculation method for discharge at the spillway of the check dam. The calculated results are compared with the measured results, which are in good agreement. However, due to limitations in our experimental design, in order to reduce errors in the calculation results, equation used in this study has certain limitations: the Froude number applicable to debris flow is 1.55–3.38; volume concentration of mud and sand in debris flow is 0.182–0.667; longitudinal slope of gully is 0.087–0.158. It should be noted that the calculation expression in this study is applicable to the condition that the check dam is filled with sediments.
(5)
We have discussed the influencing factors of overflow, mainly including debris flow factors, channel factors, and spillway factors. Furthermore, we compared our results with previous research findings and pointed out the advantages of our research.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
ack.p: This study was funded by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 42201095) and the Postdoctoral Research Project Special Funding of Sichuan (Grant No. TB2023028).

sec.title: Conflict of Interest
sec.p: The authors have no conflicts to disclose.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Wen-tao Zhang: Conceptualization (equal); Data curation (equal); Formal analysis (equal); Investigation (equal); Methodology (equal); Writing – original draft (equal). Jin-feng Liu: Funding acquisition (equal); Writing – review & editing (equal). Zheng-xuan Xu: Supervision (equal). Ping He: Supervision (equal). Yong You: Supervision (equal). Hao Sun: Supervision (equal). Hua-quan Yang: Supervision (equal).

sec.title: DATA AVAILABILITY
sec.p: The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.
